title: 103_s1539
content:
The Act may be cited as the "1995 Franklin Delano Roosevelt Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges the significant contributions of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who served as the 32nd President of the United States from 1932 until his death in 1945. He was the only President elected to four terms in office and also served as Governor of New York and Assistant Secretary of the Navy. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the 32nd President of the United States, led the country through the Great Depression and World War II. He established Social Security, authored "The Four Freedoms," founded the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, and was a key figure in the creation of the United Nations. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary will issue 500,000 one dollar silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The coins will feature a likeness of Franklin Delano Roosevelt and various inscriptions. Any design alterations require approval from the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission. The coins will be legal tender. The coins issued under this Act will be legal tender and numismatic items according to specific sections of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for each coin will be selected by the Secretary after consulting with the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission. The coins will be sold as legal tender and numismatic items. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

Coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing them. Prepaid orders will be accepted at a discount, and a $10 surcharge per coin is required.

SEC. 7. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS. The coins authorized under this Act will be available for issue starting January 1, 1995, for a 1-year period in uncirculated and proof qualities. Only one facility of the Bureau of the Mint can strike a specific denomination and quality combination. Additionally, procurement regulations do not apply to goods or services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales under this Act will be split equally between the National Park Foundation and the National Park Service for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial.

SEC. 10. AUDITS.

The Comptroller General can audit the accounts related to the surcharge distribution.

SEC. 11. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 11. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES.

The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for minting coins. Payment or security must be provided before issuing coins.
